hackathon-description-text: Welcome to the Spring 2015 hackNY Student Hackathon!
hackathon-eligibility: All projects must be submitted on Challenge Post by Sunday 11:30 AM, March 8th. Teams can be up to 4 members and all projects must be started at hackNY. All team members must be enrolled in an undergraduate or graduate degree program at the time of submission.
hackathon-requirements:
Participants should submit a project to be eligible to present. Presentation length will be decided based on how many submissions we recieve.
Projects must be functioning demos. Powerpoints and slides are extremely discouraged.
Rob Spectre: Dev Evangelist/Referee/Twilio
hackathon-rules: All projects must be submitted on Challenge Post by Sunday 11:30 AM, March 8th. Teams can be up to 4 members and all projects must be started at hackNY. All team members must be enrolled in an undergraduate or graduate degree program at the time of submission.

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: A prize for not being any of the hacks mentioned in this blog post:

$500 from Civic Hall's Andrew Rasiej + Mentoring from ChallengePost's Brandon Kessler for the best open source hack that showcases and maps Harlem’s growing tech ecosystem. This is associated with a longer challenge starting 3/8. For details and sample data go to
Linode - Best project posted on hosted on a Linode server wins Raspberry Pi's for the team members
USB Speaker system for the best use of Bluemix

hackathon-location-google-maps: https://maps.google.com/?q=Columbia University, 530 West 120th Street, New York, NY 10027, USA

hackathon-judging-criteria.judging-criterion:
That's it. No hockey sticks, no market. Just awesomeness.

Huge thanks to the s2015 Judging referee who will field any questions:

Rob Spectre;
Dev Evangelist/Referee/Twilio

hackathon-location-address: Columbia University, 530 West 120th Street, New York, NY 10027, USA
hackathon-description-header: hackNY aims to federate the next generation of hackers for the New York innovation community.
